children.value: WebGL capabilities can vary quite dramatically between browsers (from minimal WebGL 1 (e.g. headless-gl) to WebGL 1 with dozens of extensions to full WebGL 2, which also has a growing number of extensions). Unfortunately, the raw WebGL API sometimes expose the same functionalities through APIs that are slightly different and not exactly compatible.
To simplify detecting and working with conditionally available capabilities (or "features") luma.gl provides:

A set of functions that enable you to check if the application is currently running on an environment that supports a certain feature (regardless of whether it is supported through e.g. WebGL 2 or a WebGL 1 extension).

In addition, luma.gl's WebGL classes transparently use WebGL extensions or WebGL 2 APIs as appropriate, meaning that the amount of conditional logic in application code can be kept to a minimum. Once you have established that a capability exists, luma.gl offers you one unified way to use it.
Check if a feature is available (whether as a WebGL 1 or WebGL 2 extension or through WebGL 2)
// Will work both on WebGL 1 (via extension) and WebGL 2 via the standard API
// Checks if `Query` objects can do async queries of GPU timings
// Alternatively - do the same query using raw extensions
There are a few additional capability query functions sprinkled through the luma.gl API. In particular, WebGL 2 specific classes have an
method that duplicates some of the queryies that can be made using the capability system
Allows the app to query whether a capability is supported without being concerned about how it is being provided (WebGL 2, an extension etc)
) - capability name (can be a webgl extension name or a luma.gl
Allows the app to query whether a capability is supported without being concerned about how it is being provided (WebGL 2, an extension etc)
) - capability name (can be a webgl extension name or a luma.gl
This function returns an object containing all available features.

properties.ariaLabel: webgl 2 classes with some webgl 1 support permalink

children.value: WebGL 2 Classes with some WebGL 1 support
Note that luma has a few WebGL 2 classes that
. Can be instanitated under WebGL 1 if the commonly supported extension is available. Also, luma.gl treats the global vertex array as a "default" VertexArrayObject, so that can always be accessed.
objects use GPU timing extensions if available. They can always be created but obviously queries will fail if capabilities are not present.
- this class does not create any WebGL resources, it just helps the application access memory in the layout format expected by WebGL 2 uniform buffers.
method that you can call instead of checking for WebGL 2.

properties.ariaLabel: webgl 2 classes that only work in webgl 2 permalink

children.value: WebGL 2 Classes that only work in WebGL 2
A list of luma classes that can only be instantiated under WebGL 2:
- an array of textures, e.g. a texture atlas
- holds a separate set of texture sampler parameters
- holds a list of output buffers for shaders to write to.
Each of these classes has a static
method that you can call instead of checking for WebGL 2.
A partial list of features that are only available in WebGL 2:
Non-power-of-2 textures - non-POT textures can have mipmaps in WebGL 2
Integer based texture formats and attributes -
Guaranteed texture access in vertex shaders - WebGL 1 is not required to support this (although it often does)

The WebGL standard comes with an elaborate "extension" system allowing applications to check for the availability of features beyond the base WebGL 1 and WebGL 2 standards. These extensions tend to be rather technical, plus they have to be used differently in WebGL 1 and WebGL 2, so luma provides a simplified feature detection system. Following table lists all the available features, and their support under WebGL 1 and WebGL 2 ,
implies not supported, 'YES' implies supported and
) textures can be created and set as samplers (Note that filtering and rendering need to be queried separately, even in WebGL 2)
) textures can be created and set as samplers
s can have multiple color attachments that fragment shaders can access, see
s are renderable and readable, i.e. can be attached to
s and written to from fragment shaders, and read from with
etc. Note that the formats include
Blending with 32-bit floating point color buffers
Depth buffers can be stored in
s, e.g. for shadow map calculations
Linear texture filtering for floating point textures
Linear texture filtering for half float textures
Fragment shader can draw to multiple render targets
Fragment shader can control fragment depth value
Derivative functions are available in GLSL
WebGL 1 only supports one color buffer format (RBG32F is deprecated)
WebGL 2 supports multiple color buffer formats
Some extensions will not be enabled until they have been queries. luma always queries on startup to enable, app only needs to query again it wants to test platform.
The capability detection system works regardless of whether the app is running in a browser or in headless mode under Node.js.
Naturally, given that queries to driver and GPU are typically expensive in WebGL, the capabilities system will cache any queries.
